title: That feeling when Riot buffs Lee cause he: "..become a rare sight in the professional scene..."

replies.body:
There's an easy way to fix this problem.

Stop watching LCS.

Stop watching professional streamers on Twitch.

Totally ignore the existence of eSports and turn it into a giant festering monetary sinkhole that Riot can't afford to put any effort into.  Actively sabotage it by refusing to buy RP until it is gone.  And then, maybe, Riot will balance the game around the people who play it.

Personally I don't give 2 shits about the eSports scene, but apparently some people are really into it. No idea why...........I mean, why waste time watching someone else play a game when you can be playing it yourself?

> [{quoted}](name=L Psy Congroo,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=A6EXmrUA,comment-id=00030000,timestamp=2016-09-07T23:23:14.950+0000)
>No idea why...........I mean, why waste time watching someone else play a game when you can be playing it yourself?

Is this question targeted at Esports or all sports in general?

I take that stance with ALL sports. I have absolutely no interest in attending or spectating a game. I do, however, still appreciate amazing plays, but I'm not going to sit and watch the full game just hoping for something cool to happen. I will enjoy watching the cool play, but I don't care about the comparatively boring things that happen before and after.

End result of this: I do not watch any professional sport or follow any competitive team, but I watch lots of Random LoL Moments  =P

https://i.imgur.com/1HvNiEO.png?noredirect
Some people watch it because they love the way the game is played at the upper levels, and how strategic it is. Also, certain little tricks can help you improve a lot in your gameplay.

The reason people watch sports is to see people "representing" them (their team of choice) perform feats of skill, strength, or strategy that the normal person cannot. I think there is a certain joy people find in that, although I do not feel the same.

League is an online free to play game, other sports need minor monetary investment (gear) and local people to play with. League has millions of players at the ready and only needs a computer which almost everyone has.

If you want to do proper long jumping without a pit, go for it.
I already stopped buying RP. Even when I really wanted to. Only new skin I got was Project Leona from that disruption promo a few weeks ago, and that was all IP.

You're forgetting that LCS is a big part why League is so big.
Literally every patch to date has been for us, except for a handful of ones that strictly focus on pro scene that also happens to be on a yearly basis.

Stop acting like a jealous child.
WW is up for a rework, Yi and Xin, WW and Shyvanna are too simple, effective and snowbally when they are good enough for LCS. What you need to do is get your head out of your ass and stop being a meta sheep. Try these champions yourself and see if they work or not, don't follow a shitty trend of "nobody plays them, then that means they're crap".

As for a "where's this champ's rework" standpoint, unless  you want another Mordekaiser and Skarner, you'll sit your ass down and wait for a viable direction for them. Or they'll be turned into a horrible patch job that you'll inevitably still find a reason to complain about.

i mean all champs dont have to be equal but i would like most champs viable now what im about to say may rustle some jimmies but it has to be said look at dota2 most of their heroes are viable  alot more than leagues champions and yeah dota 2 if my memory serves me has a roster = to league if not larger or smaller give or take  but that still says something dota 2s heros have more viability than leagues where teams make comps on the flavor of the patch champions then just building a comp that works well with each other (now this changes with each elo) and now champion viability changes with elo as you but heres the thing Dota 2s heros most are viable regardless of what elo your in now that says something

Most of Dota 2's heroes are viable because they play on a counterpick status. Every hero there has some other heroes that completely counter that first one in a way he is useless the entire game. That way, there are strong champions, but the heroes that counter them get super strong as well because they are the only way to stop them. And that is because Dota 2's heroes are completely broken.

I mean, people freak out with 55% win rate Yasuo but Dota has some heroes over constant 60% win rate.

True but i mean you still get to see a good number of dota heros and thats a thing absolute counters i would love to see stuff like that in league to me it just puts alot more power in your pick and it atleasts makes heros viable no matter what cause they counter anther hero witch again makes your picks more important

To me, absolute counters is pretty bad to the game. Imagine the first pick picking his better champion, the one he loves to play, and then a douchebag enemy picks its absolute counter and then the first picker cant do shit the whole game. But he also had no choice, because he was a first pick.

You're asking the right questions. What IS the point of these champions?

Unfortunately they were created in an era where League was a lot simpler. There were no Yasuos, Ekkos, Azirs (although not rn), and other things. But while some of these champs are complete cancer (IMHO), they are ALSO more interesting to watch than Xin Zhao. These champs can make more choices, play different styles, and are more open to player expression and skill than the others.

Additionally and unfortunately a lot of people would just much rather watch the overloaded champs like the Yasuos and Ekkos than other champs.

> These champs can make more choices, play different styles, and are more open to player expression and skill than the others.

Hmm I'd argue with this one..
Simple champs like Yi/Xin/Udyr were very elastic when it came to builds. AP, AD, semi-bruiser-ish tanks. Lots of options.

While overloaded champs such as Lee? You have to follow 1 build and on top of that you have to play it exactly the same every time...

Some champs just don't bring what pros need even if they're perfectly fine in normal games. Such as master yi- in general with junglers pros are looking for things like being able to jump walls for more gank paths, and can unload their damage or cc very quickly I think? So even when yi volibear and syndra were OP as hell earlier this year, pros weren't really interested in them. 

Garen's not likely to ever be a competitive champ either without a full rework, but that doesn't mean he's unplayable in solo queue.

Gnar can wall jump.... albeit its cringe worthy how low i get solo jungling in customs... but its fun... also they havent givin him hunters machete in reccomended items... when he takes smite... rito plz.
he's a terrible jungler lol. I meant he's good top lane
Because league has a casual side to the game as well. These champions also were mostly made from back when the game wasnt very big and didnt even have a competitive aspect.

Their point of existence is for new players. Easier to play WW, slap W, and R the enemy carry than it is to play Lee, land a Q that is good to go in on, go in on it, ward hop behind their carry, and ult them into your team.

However, Riot has stated that no champ should cease to be viable just because you aren't in Bronze anymore.

Even the most basic champions are supposed to have enough of a skill ceiling that plat+ players still have a reason to pick them.

Unfortunately, Riot is terrible at implementing said philosophy and will need until at least 2020 to overhaul the most outdated kits...and only the worst cases unless they seriously ramp up their release speed on VGUs.
